DOC.HEAD: Airlines Considering Fuel Surcharges on Tickets
Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs to CORRECT punctuation of `decision's'; PICKS UP 11th graf pvs, `The airline...
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines, Trans World Airlines and Eastern Airlines said Friday they were considering new surcharges on tickets to help cover the skyrocketing cost of jet fuel. Other airlines also may be weighing the measure, which if imposed would be the first special fuel surcharge by the airlines since the 1970s oil crisis. ``It is a fare increase,'' said Louis Marckesano, an airline analyst at the Philadelphia brokerage Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. ``It's going to raise the cost of the ticket.'' A fuel surcharge likely would be figured into fares rather than charged separately, analysts suggested. They speculated the airlines might charge around $3 per ticket. Earlier this week, in an effort to lure passengers during the slow winter months, the nation's big airlines cut fares as much as 30 percent in selected markets. Oil prices have been catapulted higher recently by the record-setting cold snap and refinery problems in Texas and Louisiana. Jet fuel, which represents around 35 percent of an airline's operating budget, has jumped to 96 cents a gallon from 64 cents at the end of October. Every 1 cent rise in the price of jet fuel costs U.S. airlines a total $150 million a year, according to the Air Transport Association, an industry group in Washington, D.C. ``It has been a precipitous and unprecedented increase in fuel prices ... considering there hasn't been a disruption in supplies,'' said Robin Matell, a spokesman for Eastern at its headquarters in Miami. ``We're reviewing the situation and suspect other carriers are doing the same. In that sense, a surcharge cannot be ruled out.'' Don Morrison, a TWA spokesman in St. Louis, Mo., said, ``We're in the process of looking at some fuel data. We are looking at some possibilities.'' United, the nation's second-largest airline, also is pondering a charge, said Rob Doughty, a spokesman in Chicago. ``We're looking at it; no decision's been made,'' he said. The airline spokesmen all declined to give further details. On Thursday, explaining a new hike in Northeast shuttle fares from $99 one way to $119 on weekdays, Trump Shuttle cited increased costs for fuel and other expenses. Trump Shuttle officials weren't immediately available for comment Friday on whether they were weighing a surcharge as well. Spokesmen for Delta Air Lines, USAir Group Inc. and Pan Am Corp. said those airlines were not considering a fuel surcharge at the present time. A special fuel surcharge would not require government approval for domestic flights. Such a charge hasn't been imposed in the United States since 1973, when oil prices rose steeply and the federal government allowed the airlines to raise fares a few dollars to help cover costs. The U.S. airline industry was deregulated in October 1978. Since then, other types of surcharges have been instituted _ for airport security and for the Airport and Airway Trust Fund. Some U.S. carriers, such as Pan Am and TWA, add $5 to the cost of a trans-Atlantic ticket to cover security screening for international flights. The aviation trust fund is supplied by an 8 percent tax that is included in fares. Because of pressure to reduce the federal budget deficit, neither the White House nor Congress has been willing to dip into the fund, which hit $6.9 billion in September. Under legislation before Congress, the money would be released to pay for devices to detect plastic explosives in baggage. ``Fuel surcharges are a way of life in Europe,'' said Paul Turk, an analyst with consulting firm Avmark Inc. in Arlington, Va.
